Award.AwardTitle: Scaffolding Mastery Motivation: Testing a Theoretical Model of Teacher Practice and Preschoolers' Mathematics Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project testing a theoretical model of child development that examines the relation of a preschool teacher intervention to children's mathematics learning. Specifically, the project investigates a two-step causal model that examines one aspect of children's school readiness skills "mastery motivation" as a mediating variable of teacher practice to children's mathematics learning. Mastery motivation is a child's independent persistence to accomplish moderately challenging tasks, which has been found to be both a key individual difference variable and a malleable factor. The project's central hypothesis is that a teacher professional development intervention that (1) shows teachers how to pose challenging mathematics activities; (2) supports teachers in scaffolding mastery motivation (persistence); and (3) changes teachers' beliefs about learning will influence children's mastery motivation and mathematics learning. The sample includes approximately 60 preschool teachers and 600 low-income children in Head Start centers. The study contributes to knowledge about the malleable classroom factors that influence at-risk preschool children's readiness to engage successfully in elementary mathematics as articulated in the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics (CCSSM).

The CCSSM define a challenging set of expectations for elementary students. The Content Standards delineate for each grade the mathematical content students are expected to know and understand. The Standards for Mathematical Practice (SMP) are quite different, addressing the mathematical thinking and habits of mind that children should develop across content areas and across grade levels. SMP1 directly relates to mastery motivation: to make sense of problems and to persevere in solving them. However, meeting the increased expectations of the CCSSM will be particularly difficult for children who enter kindergarten underprepared. Research has shown that early mathematics understanding significantly predicts school achievement, and children from low-income backgrounds achieve at a much lower level than others. Understanding that mastery motivation, or the ability to persist at challenging tasks, is a habit of mind emphasized by CCSSM and a key school readiness skill may encourage teachers to adapt their instructional practices to promote this aspect of children's development.

Typically, preschool teachers do not teach mathematics and often feel uncomfortable with how to do so in a developmentally appropriate way. By showing teachers how to play challenging mathematics games with children and giving teachers skills to scaffold persistence, this project provides support for teaching mathematics in a fun, appropriate, and challenging way. The games are adapted from the kindergarten activities in the Think Math!Â©2008 elementary mathematics curriculum developed at EDC and engage children in problem-solving, puzzling, and discussing strategies as they play. This work expands the research foundation in STEM learning, integrating two theoretical frameworks from developmental psychology: mastery motivation and beliefs about learning into mathematics education research. Understanding the malleable factors that influence children's learning is important for practitioners and policymakers who are considering ways to help at-risk preschoolers' mathematics development.

While this study investigates mastery motivation as a foundation for mathematics learning, mastery motivation is also related to general academic and school success indicators; therefore, the results are of even broader interest in the field. Moreover, the results may suggest that interventions that enhance instructional practices in preschool would be an important line of investigation, could be of particular value in closing the school readiness gap for low-income children, and better prepare all children to meet the increased expectations of the CCSSM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this exploratory ECR study, we investigated one aspect of children's cognitive development, mastery motivation--or persistence at solving challenging tasks--as a key variable relating to children's mathematics learning. With the ultimate goal of closing the school readiness gap for preschoolers from low-income backgrounds, the Young Mathematicians (YM) study developed games as challenging problem-solving activities with a corresponding professional development (PD) module for early childhood teachers in Head Start settings. YM aims to: (1) encourage the teaching of mathematics to preschool children in fun, developmentally appropriate ways, (2) strengthen teachers' instructional practice in mathematics, and (3) engage teachers in supporting the development of children's mastery motivation and mathematics learning.

To investigate how mastery motivation might relate to children's mathematics outcomes, classrooms were assigned to one of three conditions: (1) business-as-usual (BAU); (2) classroom mathematics games and math-only PD (MathGames); and (3) classroom mathematics games and math PD plus additional PD on supporting mastery motivation (MathGames+). The MathGames PD condition was designed to develop teachers' knowledge of early mathematics content and concepts and promote high-quality mathematics instructional practice. The MathGames+ condition included the MathGames PD but added two more content strands: 1) addressing teachers' attitudes and beliefs about learning and teaching mathematics; and 2) developing teachers' strategies for scaffolding children's mastery motivation.

YM games. The YM games collectively focus on number, operations, geometry, pattern and structure. The YM games are novel as they are intentionally designed to promote persistence, problem-solving, puzzling, and discussion of problem-solving strategies, in ways that promote the development of mathematics, as well as foster adult-child mathematics talk. The games are also designed to allow for multiple entry points such that 3-year-olds to 5-year-olds can be using the same materials but learning and practicing different skills. The game format also allows children to repeatedly play the games with increasing mathematical sophistication over time, all while practicing key mathematical concepts known to bolster children's school readiness skills in fun and developmentally appropriate ways.

Teacher guide. The teacher guide includes a description of the key mathematical content and concepts in each game, a formative assessment tool for teachers to see and document children's mathematical thinking and progress, picture book titles and ways to use books that link to key mathematical ideas, and ways to modify the games to increase or decrease the level of challenge.

Teacher PD. Teachers attended seven 1.5-hour in-person PD sessions designed to strengthen their understanding of early mathematics concepts, enact the classroom games, and support teachers' ability to observe the mathematical thinking children display while playing the games. The MathGames+ PD is innovative in its use of games as a vehicle to effectively address the importance of adults' positive attitudes toward mathematics while attending to teachers' mindsets about learning and how that may impact children's learning. Moreover, the MathGames+ PD specifically supports teachers to promote children's persistence and positive beliefs about learning while implementing challenging mathematics tasks. 

Findings. In 2015-2016, we conducted a study of YM using a randomized control trial (RCT) with 64 teachers and 559 preschoolers at four Head Start sites. Classrooms were assigned to one of the three conditions: (1) business-as-usual (BAU); (2) MathGames (math-only PD); or (3) MathGames+ (included added content on supporting mastery motivation). Pre- and post-intervention, we measured teachers' beliefs about learning, observed teacher-child interaction during mathematics activities, assessed children's mastery motivation and mathematics learning, and measured the extent of use of mathematics games in intervention classrooms. We collected teacher background information and assessed teachers' anxiety about mathematics. Importantly, we found that children's fall mastery motivation was positively related to their spring mathematics scores, even after controlling for fall mathematics scores, indicating that mastery motivation plays an important and distinct role in promoting children's mathematics learning. MathGames+ also had a positive effect on Head Start preschool teachers' confidence in teaching mathematics. Additional analyses also pointed to the importance of attending to teachers' anxieties about mathematics during PD. Moreover, the MathGames+ approach attends to both the needs of young children learning mathematics and teachers learning to teach mathematics, with a particular emphasis on supporting teachers in enactment. Overall, the evidence gathered to date on the YM program indicates that the MathGames+ condition has promise for impacting low-income preschool children's mathematics learning and that teachers' beliefs and attitudes are important factors that may influence mathematics outcomes.

This project has contributed to the field of early childhood mathematics educational research by providing a unique model for integrating PD and instructional materials that address both teacher and student needs by attending to the importance of children's mastery motivation and teachers' attitudes and beliefs about mathematics. By providing careful attention to age-appropriate mathematics concepts and to the social-cognitive supports necessary to learn mathematics, YM has the potential to broaden participation in mathematics by improving learning outcomes in mathematics for preschoolers from under-resourced backgrounds.
